newsitem.title: DUBAI: FUJAIRAH BUNKER PRICES REVISIT JANUARY HIGHS.
newsitem.headline: FUJAIRAH BUNKER PRICES REVISIT JANUARY HIGHS.

text.p: Fujairah 380-cst bunker prices have hit their highest levels since January because of tight promptness in Singapore and strong Gulf demand, traders based in the United Arab Emirates said on Thursday.
The grade was quoted at $102-$103 a tonne, the strongest numbers since January 16.
"The numbers have tracked Singapore...the market here is also showing good demand," said one Fujairah broker.
Bunker sellers pointed to the resumption of Iraqi exports under the United Nations "oil-for-food" deal as bullish.
Tanker owners lifting from Iraq's Minal al-Bakr terminal would take on fuel at Gulf bunkering ports in the UAE, Oman, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait.
But other brokers said that weaker crude and fuel oil prices as a result of Iraqi crude flows would quickly feed through into lower 380-cst prices at the UAE port.
"There must be a correction...Prices went up too quick," another trader in the OPEC country said.
The upturn in Gulf bunker spot prices has led state oil firms in the region to hike their posted prices.
Saudi Aramco and National Iranian Oil Company (NIOC) on Wednesday announced price increases of up to $3 a tonne and $4 a tonne respectively effective August 7.
